title: Ex-White House aide feared Gordon Sondland posed security risk: report
text:
Gordan Sondland, the U.S. ambassador to the EU | European Union Ex-White House aide feared Gordon Sondland posed security risk: report Former foreign policy adviser reportedly told House impeachment investigators she had concerns about US ambassador to the EU.

A former White House foreign policy adviser was concerned Gordon Sondland could pose a national security risk as EU ambassador because he was unprepared for the job, according to the New York Times.

Fiona Hill expressed these concerns to House impeachment investigators this week, but did not accuse Sondland of intentionally putting the country in danger, the newspaper reported, citing two unnamed people familiar with Hill’s private testimony.

Sondland — a hotel magnate and major donor to Donald Trump before becoming ambassador — is among those set to testify in the impeachment probe over efforts to pressure Ukrainian officials to investigate the U.S. president’s political rivals. The U.S. State Department initially blocked the EU ambassador, whose text messages revealed by lawmakers indicated he was aware of such efforts, from appearing before investigators. But after receiving a subpoena, Sondland’s attorney said his client would appear before the three committees spearheading the probe on Thursday.

Hill, the president's former top Russia adviser, was the first White House official to cooperate in the Democrats' investigation of the Ukraine scandal. According to the New York Times’ report, Hill described Sondland metaphorically as driving in an unfamiliar place with no guardrails and no GPS.

She said she thought Sondland’s actions made him vulnerable to foreign governments due to his inexperience, and described how he often used a personal cellphone for official diplomatic matters.

Hill also said Sondland would repeatedly tell foreign officials they could visit the White House whenever they wanted, prompting one instance in which Romanian officials showed up at the president’s residence without an appointment.

She reportedly told investigators that Sondland would provide the cellphone numbers of American officials to foreigners, which posed a counterintelligence risk, according to the report.

Hill said she and her boss, then national security adviser John Bolton, were so concerned by what they saw that she went to White House lawyers.
description: Former foreign policy adviser reportedly told House impeachment investigators she had concerns about US ambassador to the EU.
